Dialogue: Likewise, Miss Nadine.   What can I do for you?

Dialogue: You know what you can do for me, sweet man.

Dialogue: What would you like to drink?

Dialogue: How many is that tonight?

Dialogue: Don't dog me about that, baby.   Not tonight.

Dialogue: I don't want China Doll behind that bar.

Dialogue: Viola Underwood found the Lord.

Dialogue: I thought she found Him last year when they come through.

Dialogue: The Spirit didn't move you, though?

Speaker: delilah
Dialogue: Not yet.   Might be too late for me.

Dialogue: I can't believe you're serving Alton Stokely.

Dialogue: Stokely has to use two hands to keeps his glass steady as he drinks-  DELILAH  Toussaint cut his credit off. Either he gets it here-

Dialogue: He's gonna drink himself to death in here.

Dialogue: Least he won't go blind first.

Dialogue: Imonna go home and say a prayer for that man.

Dialogue: Thanks. Hey, what's the name of this town?  Shack points to the SIGN hanging down from the lip of the platform roof-

Dialogue: The sign reads-

Dialogue: Only night I ever spent in jail was a town called Liberty. Sun comes up, you'll see where you landed. And you best be out of that shed by first light.

Dialogue: I owe the chicken man, I owe the ice man, I owe the liquor man-

Dialogue: Least you don't owe the electric company.

Dialogue: Yeah, that's a big relief.

Dialogue: What you think?

Dialogue: Damn-

Dialogue: Guitar Sam at the Honeydripper. Man, this joint is going to jump!

Dialogue: I knew this was Alabama, but that's the Stone Ages, man.

Dialogue: You better get pickin.

Dialogue: You got my sympathies.

Dialogue: Been doin it near forever.

Dialogue: The wrong side for you.

Dialogue: You in a hurry?

Dialogue: I smell bacon.

Dialogue: You got one waitin for you if you want her.

Dialogue: Don't see no problem with that.

Dialogue: Nadine look like she can take care of those, too-

Dialogue: You eat chicken every morning, noon and night for five months, you get a taste for some different kind of meat, right?  Maybe I shouldn't be-

Dialogue: You got to admit it, though- woman is an artist with that Singer machine.

Dialogue: We aint hirin.

Dialogue: I can play anything-

Dialogue: Already got me a professional.

Dialogue: That so surprising?

Dialogue: No, no-- uhm, Mr. Shack Thomas said that if I was to-

Dialogue: You know Shack?

Dialogue: We uh- we travelled together-

Dialogue: That's real kind of you-

Dialogue: I help you gentlemen?

Dialogue: Just showing the man gonna run this place what he's got.

Dialogue: This is my place.

Dialogue: You the piano player, right?

Dialogue: Pinetop Purvis who owes two hundred dollars to Lucky Hardaway up in Little Rock-

Dialogue: He's gonna get his-

Dialogue: Pinetop who missed last month's rent-

Dialogue: Lucky give me two weeks-

Dialogue: Lucky got a better offer.

Dialogue: He can't do that.

Dialogue: You don't think so?

Dialogue: What if we got our payment for him Monday?

Dialogue: Saturday night.

Dialogue: We can do that-

Dialogue: Not just a taste- the whole two hundred.

Dialogue: And I throw in a twenny-five cent tip for his messenger boy.

Dialogue: I'll be here.

Dialogue: You seen enough, Mr. Simmons?

Dialogue: Yeah, somebody could make something out of this place. Wouldn't take much work at all.

Dialogue: We cleared over two hundred that one weekend-

Dialogue: Couple years back-

Dialogue: And we didn't have no Louisiana guitar wizard playin neither.

Dialogue: Yeah, they say he draws em like flies.

Dialogue: That's what they say.

Dialogue: I already sent fifty to his manager.

Dialogue: How much you payin him all out?

Dialogue: Another hundred.

Dialogue: We'd have to clear three hundred-

Dialogue: I figure we charge folks two dollars to get in, then drinks-

Dialogue: What I'm sayin is, less he sees the green up front the man won't get off the train.

Dialogue: What's that now?

Dialogue: Bout time you fellas run by. We just about dry here.

Dialogue: Your boss in?

Dialogue: Tyrone!   Whiskey wagon come by!

Dialogue: Y'all a day late.

Dialogue: Old Man Toussaint gonna chew you out.

Dialogue: My credit no good anymore?

Dialogue: Whoah, whoah- what's your hurry?

Dialogue: I'll pay you extra- penny a bottle on the beer and a nickel on the whiskey!

Dialogue: What if I throw in five dollars up front, just for you fellas- ?

Dialogue: Come on, man, everybody give credit, that's the American way!

Dialogue: Maybe we could buy some busthead from Willie Pettigrew.

Dialogue: Then what we gonna do?

Dialogue: That's-

Dialogue: That would be me.

Dialogue: I trust they got my check all right?

Dialogue: Don't spose I'd be here if they didn't.

Dialogue: Pull it around to the back- we'll help you unload.

Dialogue: Arkansas.    How bout you?

Dialogue: Not much happenin, little town like this.

Dialogue: Yes.

Dialogue: It's just- she got to go out in style, is what it is. The best you got, all the trimmins- lay it out for her. That's the way she lived it- that's the way she ought to leave it.

Dialogue: It meanders away from the Light and into the Darkness, it tires our legs and whittles away at our spirits!

Dialogue: It snares us with the thorns and thistles of wickedness, it is paved with the black deeds of sinners and laid out on a crooked plan! That's not the road we want to be on, Brothers and Sisters, that's not the path we need to follow!

Dialogue: We got to get on that other road! The one that leads to salvation! The one that leads to glory! The one that leads to the right hand of God! Praise His name!

Dialogue: Praise the Lord!

Dialogue: The thoroughfare I'm talking about, the righteous path we got to tread, is called the Highway to Heaven, and by the great Lord above it is straight and it is narrow!
